comment_data.body:
Can you ever end up with `arg` as something that isn't a `SliceIndexNode`? For example:

    a = some_array[1:10]
    return a

Could `a` pick up the type from the indexing operation, but the coercion would happen to a `NameNode`?

comment_data.body:
There is no guarantee that these are ints. They might be C compiler macro names, `sizeof(sometype)`, or whatever. But we can calculate this size at runtime and let the C compiler fold it for us if it can. We don't actually need to know it for the code generation.

Note also that the slice length might be zero or negative. We need to test and handle that. Min and max `Py_ssize_t` / `size_t` values are also usually worth testing, e.g. the empty slice `[max:min]`.

You can use `__Pyx_is_valid_index()` for bounds checking, but should take a look at the `boundscheck` and `wraparound` directives as well, which should disable these checks. Wraparound can also be made to work with a known array length. There is a lot of example code in `StringTools.c`.

Edit: In fact, feel free to use a Cython implemented utility function for this, instead of generating the conversion code with string formatting. See the `carray` conversion functions in `CConvert.pyx`.

comment_data.body:
This is a bit funny  why is there a `SliceIndexNode` at all, when the work is done by the `CoerceSliceArrayToList` node that wraps it? I think that's coupling both nodes too tightly.

Do we need the coercion node at all? Can't the `SliceIndexNode` simply return the Python tuple or list, and build it itself? Basically, if `self.base` is a C array or C pointer (we need tests for both), and `self.type` is `list_type` or `tuple_type`, then call the slice copying function. You can create an appropriately configured `SliceIndexNode` in its `coerce_to()` method and just return that.

I think we can also raise compile time errors when trying to coerce a C array to any builtin or extension type other than `list`/`tuple`. Oh, and `set`/`frozenset`, because why not support `<frozenset>intptr[:10]` ?

And I think we also have to take the `boundscheck` and `wraparound` directives into account.

Note that there is a slice bounds calculation function coming in from PR #3600, `__Pyx_PySlice_AdjustIndices()`, which I think we can best reuse here.

comment_data.body:
The utility code should not get compiled with whatever directives the users have set for their own code. It should be well defined.

Although, that's not entirely true. Anything that changes coercions, specifically the `c_string_type` and `c_string_encoding` directives, should best be honoured for the item conversion. E.g. a sliced `char[][]` should turn into a list with items of the user requested string type. That means we also need tests for that. You can put those into the respective `*_auto_encoding.pyx` test modules.

I think we need to build a dict of well selected directives here.

comment_data.body: Hmm, no, I meant that the `SliceIndexNode` can do the copying of the array slice part itself, rather than having a separate node do it instead. It's the purpose of the `SliceIndexNode` to do the slicing, whatever the result is. And if the result is calculated by a copy function, so be it. But it's still up to the `SliceIndexNode` to call that function, right here in this place.

comment_data.body:
I think we normally prefer splitting lines with brackets than `\`, and string formatting to concatenation:

```
to_py_func_cname = "__Pyx_slice_carray_%s_to_py_%s" % (
      self.base.type.specialization_name(), to_py_obj_type)
```

Although don't copy my indenting because I never get it right

-        if dst_type.is_array and self.base.type.is_array:

comment_data.body:
Could you largely re-use the `carray.to_py` section? Your functions would just have to work out a start and end index (taking into account wraparound) and then call the existing convension functions?

I'm also not convinced we really need a set/frozenset version - these are probably used rarely enough that they could just go through a tuple.

comment_data.body:
These tests (commented) still fails
description of bug
```
# b is initialized
b = 5555
# a can be c-array or slice of c-array
b = a[1:5]
b = a
```

then when I am trying to cast

```
print(<list> b)
print(<tuple> b)
print(<set> b)
print(<frozenset> b)
```

result will be always the list, since dst_type will be always python object, not tuple_type, ... etc.


Second bug:
when b wasn't initialized before (like in previous code example)
```
b = a[1:5]
```
or
```
b = a
```
will raise the error

I missed that comment - sorry!

Note that you can add use [`PySet_Add`](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/set.html#c.PySet_Add) on frozenset's too - you don't have to go through a tuple.

comment_data.body: Unlike `PyList_SET_ITEM` and `PyTuple_SET_ITEM` this can raise an exception. It also doesn't steal a reference, so I think you have a memory leak.

+        PySet_Add(l, value)

comment_data.body: I'm a bit worried about these two lines. I think `value` will be inferred to be `base_type`, and a new Python object will be created specifically to pass to `Py_INCREF`. Instead I think you should do `cdef object value` at the start of the function so that the conversion happens on `value = arr[i]`.

comment_data.body:
The first bug looks like an existing problem that probably doesn't need fixing here.

I think the second bug is not really a bug. If `b` isn't initialized then Cython gets it's type from the assignment. You could also do `cdef object b` to set the type of `b`.

__Pyx_PyFrozenSet_New

```
l = frozenset(l)
{{endif}}
```
by converting from tuple

comment_data.body: You are mixing signed (`i`) and unsigned types here. That's rarely a good idea in C. Just use `Py_ssize_t` for everything.

comment_data.body: There is no guarantee that this makes `from_idx` and `to_idx` >= 0. What if `to_idx` is -2000 for an array of size 5? Then it's still negative after the wrap-around above, and so will be `from_idx`.

comment_data.body: Please also test with `PY_SSIZE_T_MIN` and `PY_SSIZE_T_MAX` as boundary indices (`cdef extern from *`). See, for example, the [unicode_slicing](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/tests/run/unicode_slicing.pyx) tests. Code like `length = to_idx - from_idx` may overflow in C for sufficiently large negative values.

Test for auto encoding of sliced c-string
Add coercing of slice of c-array to Python objects
Activate ability to casting of slice of c-array to Python objects
